skills.name: Find missing angles on parallel lines using supplementary angles
Find missing angles on parallel lines using more than one angle fact

explanations.A: Alternate angles make a 'z' shape. They can be acute or obtuse.
explanations.B: Alternate angles make a 'z' shape. They can be acute or obtuse.
explanations.C: Two of these lines are parallel. 65° and y are one pair alternate angles and 103° and x are another pair of alternate angles for the same reason. Alternate angles are equal.
explanations.D: Alternate angles make a 'z' shape. They can be acute or obtuse.

explanations.A: Remember where a line crosses two parallel lines, the angles in matching positions at the intersections are corresponding. They are equal.
explanations.B: 109° and y are not alternate angles. It is impossible to say what y is without knowing more of the missing angles.
explanations.C: What type of angle, acute or obtuse, is y? What kind of angle is 109?
explanations.D: Remember where a line crosses two parallel lines, the angles in matching positions at the intersections are corresponding. They are equal.

explanations.A: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with vertically opposite angles.
explanations.B: Co-interior angles are on the inside (interior) of two parallel lines and on the same side of a crossing line. b and f are co-interior (we can ignore the middle horizontal line).
explanations.C: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with alternate angles.
explanations.D: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with corresponding angles.

explanations.A: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with corresponding angles.
explanations.B: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with corresponding angles.
explanations.C: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with vertically opposite angles.
explanations.D: Co-interior angles are on the inside (interior) of two parallel lines and on the same side of a crossing line. d and b are co-interior.

explanations.A: I think you may be confusing corresponding angles with vertically opposite angles.
explanations.B: Imagine sliding the parallel line on the left toward the right until the two intersection points overlap. The angle p will be directly over B. This means they correspond.
explanations.C: I think you may be confusing corresponding angles with alternate angles.
explanations.D: I think you may be confusing corresponding angles with co-interior angles.

explanations.A: I think you may be confusing corresponding angles with vertically opposite angles.
explanations.B: I think you may be confusing corresponding angles with co-interior angles.
explanations.C: Imagine sliding the parallel line on the left toward the right until the two intersection points overlap. The angle p will be directly over B. This means they correspond.
explanations.D: I think you may be confusing corresponding angles with alternate angles.

explanations.A: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with vertically opposite angles.
explanations.B: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with corresponding angles.
explanations.C: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with alternate angles.
explanations.D: We have two parallel lines and another line that crosses them. Co-interior angles are on the inside (interior) of the parallel lines and on the same side of the crossing line.

explanations.A: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with alternate angles.
explanations.B: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with corresponding angles.
explanations.C: We have two parallel lines and another line that crosses them. Co-interior angles are on the inside (interior) of the parallel lines and on the same side of the crossing line.
explanations.D: I think you may be confusing co-interior angles with vertically opposite angles.

explanations.A: I think you may be thinking about corresponding angles. Try thinking about co-interior angles. What will the sum be of these two angles?
explanations.B: Almost! I think you've just made a little slip in your working.
explanations.C: Angle p is co-interior to 52°. This means that p ＋ 52° = 180°, so p = 180 − 52° = 128°.
explanations.D: Try thinking about co-interior angles. What will the sum be of these two angles?

explanations.A: Angle p is co-interior to 48°. This means that p ＋ 48° = 180°, so p = 180 − 48° = 132°.
explanations.B: Almost! I think you've just made a little slip in your working.
explanations.C: I think you may be thinking about corresponding angles. Try thinking about co-interior angles. What will the sum be of these two angles?
explanations.D: Try thinking about co-interior angles. What will the sum be of these two angles?
